awd_titl_txt: Acquisition of auto analyzer system for nutrient analysis at sea
awd_abstract_narration:
Texas A&M proposes to acquire a 5-channel nutrient autoanalyzer for use at sea for the measurement of nitrate, nitrite, phosphate, silicate and ammonia during research cruises carried out by personnel from the Department of Oceanography at Texas A&M University and the Departments of Marine Biology and Marine Science at Texas A&M University, Galveston. Such measurements are currently made using samples collected at sea and frozen, then analyzed on an old Astoria-Pacific instrument at the laboratory at the Geochemical and Environmental Research Group (GERG). Having an instrument that can go to sea would mean more timely and accurate results for their programs. Texas A&M Provided technical descriptions and rationale for the acquisition of the following Oceanographic Instrumentation:	
	
1)	SEAL AA500 autoanalyzer	$100,590		

Broader Impacts
The principal impact of the present proposal is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 19-602). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF).  The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
NSF provided funding to support the purchase of a new 5-channel autoanalyzer system that simultaneously measures nitrate, nitrite, phosphate, silicate, and ammonia concentrations in seawater. A major aim of the purchase is to allow the instrument to be taken to sea, as this minimizes the amount of handling that the samples undergo before analysis, and thus is expected to yield more accurate results than freezing them and analyzing them in a shore-based laboratory. The instrument uses well-known and understood colorimetric analytical methods that have been  used successfully for many years, apart from the ammonia manifold, which uses a fluorimetric method that is more sensitive than the previous colorimetric method and gets away from the use of a toxic compound, phenol. 

 

The instrument was ordered in June 2021, and arrived at the university from Germany in November. The manufacturer provided training in December 2021. We have since tested the instrument against our existing autoanalyzer system, using preserved samples, and tests are ongoing. Additionally, we are constructing a series of transport boxes for ease of handling and to protect the instrument. To date, we have not been able to test the autoanalyzer at sea, but we anticipate doing on a research cruise later in the summer.
